focus_skills: Systems of two linear equations in two variables

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: A bakery sells muffins for $2 each and cookies for $1 each. If a customer buys 5 muffins and 3 cookies for a total of $13, which system of equations represents the prices if m is the price of a muffin and c is the price of a cookie?
questions.explanation: The system must represent the total cost and perhaps total items, but the correct one matches the purchases directly with an additional equation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify variables and set up equations based on given quantities and totals.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
<math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>
<math><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>
What is the value of a in the solution to the system above?
questions.explanation: Adding twice the second equation to the first eliminates b: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, so <math><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>, but wait, correct calculation yields a=3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use elimination or substitution to solve systems efficiently.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: If the system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> has solution (x, y), what is x?
questions.explanation: Subtract the first from the second: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Subtract equations to eliminate variables.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
<math><mn>4</mn><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>
<math><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>
What is the value of q?
questions.explanation: Subtract three times the second from the first to get p=3, then q=2.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Practice solving for one variable in terms of the other.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M0 30 H300 M0 60 H300 M0 90 H300 M0 120 H300 M0 150 H300 M0 180 H300 M0 210 H300 M0 240 H300 M0 270 H300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M30 0 V300 M60 0 V300 M90 0 V300 M120 0 V300 M150 0 V300 M180 0 V300 M210 0 V300 M240 0 V300 M270 0 V300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='290' y2='270' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='30' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='290' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='10' y='20' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>y</text><text x='20' y='285' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='90' y='285' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='150' y='285' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='210' y='285' font-size='12'>6</text><text x='15' y='215' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='15' y='155' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='15' y='95' font-size='12'>6</text><line x1='15' y1='105' x2='225' y2='285' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='60' y1='300' x2='240' y2='120' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='150' cy='210' r='4' fill='black' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A coordinate plane showing two intersecting lines. The blue line passes through the y-intercept at 6 and the x-intercept at 6. The green line passes through the x-intercept at 2 and intersects the blue line at the point (4, 2).
questions.question: The graph above shows a system of two linear equations. Which of the following systems represents the graph?
questions.explanation:
The most efficient way to solve this is to identify the **solution point** from the graph and test it in the options.

1.  **Identify the Intersection:** The graph shows the two lines intersecting at the point $(4, 2)$. This point represents the solution $(x, y) = (4, 2)$.
2.  **Test Option A:**
    * Equation 1: $4 + 2 = 6$. (True)
    * Equation 2: $4 - 2 = 2$. (True)

Since $(4, 2)$ satisfies both equations in Option A, it is the correct system.
questions.explanation_chart_description: The graph highlights the intersection point (4, 2). A text box shows the substitution check: '4 + 2 = 6' and '4 - 2 = 2', confirming the solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a graph shows an intersection point clearly, find its coordinates $(x, y)$ and plug them into the answer choices. The correct system must satisfy **both** equations.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: A store sells apples for $0.50 each and oranges for $0.75 each. If 10 fruits cost $6.25, and there are 4 more apples than oranges, how many apples were bought?
questions.explanation: Let a = apples, o = oranges. a + o = 10, a = o + 4. Solve to get a=7, but correct is 9.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up equations from word problems carefully.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
<math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>
<math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>
What is x + y?
questions.explanation: The second equation is x + y = 5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize when the sum is directly given.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: The system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> has solution (x, y). What is x?
questions.explanation: Adding equations: 3x = 12, x=4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Add equations to eliminate y.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: A total of 12 items cost $20. If notebooks cost $2 each and pens $1 each, and there are 4 more notebooks than pens, how many pens?
questions.explanation: Let p = pens, n = notebooks. n + p = 12, n = p + 4, 2n + p = 20. Solve p=4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use substitution for word problems.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
<math><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>
<math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>
What is a?
questions.explanation: Multiply second by 2: 6a + 2b = 22. Subtract from first: -a = -3, a=3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Align coefficients for elimination.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: For what value of k does the system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> have no solution?
questions.explanation: For no solution, slopes equal, intercepts different. Slope first -1/2, second -k. k=1/2 for parallel.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check for parallel lines by comparing slopes.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: A boat travels 20 km downstream in 2 hours and upstream 20 km in 5 hours. What is the speed of the boat in still water?
questions.explanation: Let b = boat speed, c = current. b + c = 10, b - c = 4. Solve b=7.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Model rates with systems.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
<math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>
<math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>
For infinite solutions, what is a?
questions.explanation: Multiply first by 3: (3/2)x + y = 3, so a=3/2.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Scale equations for equivalence.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> and the system has no solution with another equation, which could it be?
questions.explanation: B is parallel, same ratio, different constant.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check ratios for parallel lines.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in 1 variable
questions.question: Solve <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What is the sum of solutions?
questions.explanation: Sum is 5 from -b/a.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use Vieta's formulas for quadratics.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe uses 3 cups flour for 2 loaves. How many cups for 5 loaves?
questions.explanation: Proportion: 3/2 = x/5, x=7.5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up proportions for rates.

questions.skill: Right triangles and trigonometry
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M 40,150 L 40,50 L 240,150 Z' fill='white' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='40' y='140' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='30' y='165' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='30' y='45' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='250' y='165' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='10' y='100' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='130' y='170' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>x + 7</text><text x='150' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>x + 8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC with the right angle at A. The vertical leg AB has length 'x'. The horizontal leg AC has length 'x + 7'. The hypotenuse BC has length 'x + 8'.
questions.question: In the right triangle <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown above, the lengths of the sides are given in terms of <math><mi>x</mi></math>. What is the length of the hypotenuse <math><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
Using the Pythagorean theorem (<math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>), substitute the given expressions:
<math display='block'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math>

Expand the quadratic binomials:
<math display='block'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>49</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn></math>

Combine like terms and set the equation to zero:
<math display='block'><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>49</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn></math>
<math display='block'><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

Factor the quadratic equation:
<math display='block'><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>

Potential solutions for <math><mi>x</mi></math> are <math><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Since length cannot be negative, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.

Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> into the hypotenuse expression:
<math display='block'><mi>Hypotenuse</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The algebraic steps shown in a flowchart format: setting up the equation, expanding the squares, simplifying to a quadratic, factoring to find x=5, and substituting back to find the hypotenuse is 13.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When side lengths are algebraic expressions, expand <math><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math> carefully as <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Do not forget the middle term!

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
If the system of linear equations below has a solution <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>y</mi></math>?

<math display='block'><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>
<math display='block'><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>
questions.explanation: To solve for y, use the elimination method to remove x. 1. Align the equations: (1) x-0.5y=2 (2) 2x+y=10 2. Multiply equation (1) by -2 so the x terms become opposites: -2(x-0.5y)=-2(2) -2x+y=-4 3. Add this new equation to equation (2): (-2x+y)+(2x+y)=-4+10 2y=6 4. Solve for y: y=62 y=3
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M0 30 H300 M0 60 H300 M0 90 H300 M0 120 H300 M0 150 H300 M0 180 H300 M0 210 H300 M0 240 H300 M0 270 H300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M30 0 V300 M60 0 V300 M90 0 V300 M120 0 V300 M150 0 V300 M180 0 V300 M210 0 V300 M240 0 V300 M270 0 V300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='290' y2='270' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='30' y1='270' x2='30' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='290' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='10' y='20' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><text x='20' y='285' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='150' y='285' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='270' y='285' font-size='12'>8</text><text x='15' y='155' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='15' y='35' font-size='12'>8</text><line x1='60' y1='270' x2='180' y2='30' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='30' y1='10' x2='180' y2='270' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='135' cy='180' r='5' fill='red' /><text x='145' y='180' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>y = 3</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Graph of the two lines intersecting at (3.5, 3). The intersection point is highlighted in red, emphasizing the y-coordinate value of 3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If one equation has a decimal coefficient (like <math><mn>0.5</mn><mi>y</mi></math>), multiply the entire equation by a power of 10 or an integer (like 2) to clear the decimal before solving.

questions.skill: Nonlinear functions
questions.question: The graph of the function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math> intersects the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> at how many points?
questions.explanation: To determine the number of intersection points (roots), use the discriminant of the quadratic equation ax2+bx+c=0. 1. Identify the coefficients from y=x2+2x-3: a=1, b=2, c=-3 2. Calculate the discriminant (Δ): Δ=b2-4ac Δ=(2)2-4(1)(-3) Δ=4+12 Δ=16 3. Analyze the result: Since Δ>0 (16>0), the equation has 2 distinct real roots.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='170' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><path d='M 30,0 C 50,150 90,270 120,270 S 190,150 210,0' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' opacity='0.5'/><circle cx='60' cy='150' r='6' fill='red' /><circle cx='180' cy='150' r='6' fill='red' /><text x='40' y='135' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' fill='red'>Root 1</text><text x='180' y='135' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' fill='red'>Root 2</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same parabola graph with the two x-intercepts highlighted with red dots, confirming there are 2 intersection points.
questions.score_improvement_tip:
Remember the Discriminant Rules (<math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math>):
* Positive result: 2 intersection points.
* Zero result: 1 intersection point (vertex touches axis).
* Negative result: 0 intersection points (graph never touches axis).

questions.skill: Percentages
questions.question: The price of an item is first increased by <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and then the new price is decreased by <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. What is the net percent change in the price of the item? (If the price decreases, enter a negative value).
questions.explanation: To find the net percent change, you can assume the original price is 100. 1. First Change (Increase): 100×1.20=120 2. Second Change (Decrease): The 20% decrease is applied to the new price of 120, not the original 100. 120×0.80=96 3. Calculate Net Change: Final-Original=96-100=-4 The net change is a 4% decrease, so the answer is -4.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='150' viewBox='0 0 400 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><rect x='20' y='50' width='80' height='50' rx='5' ry='5' fill='#e0f7fa' stroke='black' /><text x='60' y='70' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>Original</text><text x='60' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' text-anchor='middle'>100</text><line x1='100' y1='75' x2='150' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='125' y='65' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='green' text-anchor='middle'>+20%</text><rect x='160' y='50' width='80' height='50' rx='5' ry='5' fill='#fff9c4' stroke='black' /><text x='200' y='70' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>New Price</text><text x='200' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' text-anchor='middle'>120</text><line x1='240' y1='75' x2='290' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='265' y='65' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='red' text-anchor='middle'>-20%</text><rect x='300' y='50' width='80' height='50' rx='5' ry='5' fill='#ffebee' stroke='black' /><text x='340' y='70' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>Final</text><text x='340' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' text-anchor='middle'>96</text><path d='M 60,110 Q 200,160 340,110' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><text x='200' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='blue' text-anchor='middle'>Net Change: -4%</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: A flowchart showing the price calculation steps: starting at 100, adding 20% results in 120, then subtracting 20% from 120 results in 96. A curved dashed line connects the start (100) and end (96) showing a net difference of -4%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Do not simply add the percentages (<math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></math>). Apply them sequentially: <math><mn>1.20</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.96</mn></math>.
